boardgame.description:
Description from the publisher:

The Great Old Ones' insidious reach continues to spread and Curse of the Jade Emperor, the second Asylum Pack of the Ancient Relics cycle, follows the tendrils of evil into the Far East. Prepare for restless dead, secret societies, and unholy artifacts!

Ancient Relics is based on the theme of the global influence of the Ancient Ones and their cults and moves the action from H.P. Lovecraft's dread-filled New England to the wider world. In Curse of the Jade Emperor players will find exotic, yet hauntingly familiar characters and tales, pulled from the myths and legends of ancient China. The Middle Kingdom's undying past collides with a present made all the more uncertain through the interference of diverse otherworldly actors.

The pull of China is strong and in Call of Cthulhu it attracts academics from Miskatonic University, eager to study the history and artifacts of one of the world's oldest civilizations. The forces of law and order also come to do battle with some of the world's deadliest criminal organizations. Curse of the Jade Emperor also follows Ancient Relics' over-arching theme of artifacts with great and terrible power reoccurring throughout history. Pack your bags for a voyage to the Orient in Curse of the Jade Emperor!

Secrets and mysteries abound in a classic Asylum Pack, which is emerging from the shadows to crawl back into the light. Conspiracies of Chaos, the fifth Asylum Pack in the Forgotten Lore cycle of expansions for Call of Cthulhu: The Card Game, returns!

Conspiracies of Chaos reintroduces to the Living Card Game environment this intriguing Asylum Pack, updated to the 60-card per pack format (three copies each of 20 unique cards). The included cards have been updated to incorporate the most recent FAQ. In addition, the text on a number of cards has been altered from its original printing, adjusting for game balance and rules clarity.

Among Conspiracies of Chaos' features are six faction-specific conspiracies. Conspiracies are story cards that players can play from their own decks and win to further their goal of claiming three stories. The six conspiracies included within Conspiracies of Chaos play into one of each faction’s particular strengths. Also featured are an assortment of characters that thrive in a world of conspiracy–characters that grow stronger when a conspiracy is in play. In addition, this Asylum Pack also includes support cards and events that can wildly alter the tempo of the game.

boardgame.name: Charlie and the Chocolate Factory
Charlie und die Schokoladen-Fabrik
Charlie y la Fbrica de Chocolate
Sjakie en de Chocoladefabriek
boardgame.description:
Charlie and the Chocolate Factory is a 2005 video game which was released on the Xbox, PlayStation 2, Nintendo GameCube, Game Boy Advance, and Windows platforms. It is based on the film of the same name by Tim Burton. The game was released in the middle of the year to coincide with the release of the film in theatres. Most of the main cast from the film provided their voices for the game except for Johnny Depp, and James Arnold Taylor was used in his place as the voice of Willy Wonka.

Original Music for the video game was created by Winifred Phillips and produced by Winnie Waldron.

The first objective of the game is to help Charlie find money to buy a Wonka Bar to win a Golden Ticket. This is done at the beginning of the game while giving a tutorial of what controls will be needed during future stages.

The main part of the game takes place in Willy Wonka's chocolate factory where the Oompa Loompas help the player through each level. By giving them commands Charlie finishes each challenge and progresses through the game. Each Oompa Loompa specializes in different tasks, such as electrical work, harvesting and welding. Candy is scattered throughout the levels and when collected it boosts Charlie's energy.

Each level is very similar to the plot in the 2005 movie. For example, Charlie must help Willy Wonka remove the gluttonus Augustus Gloop from the pipe above the chocolate river. He must roll the blueberry Violet Beauregarde to the Juicing Room and juice her. When Veruca Salt is thrown down the garbage chute, the player's objective is to follow her down the chute and save her from the incinerator. The last objective of the game is after Mike Teavee shrinks himself the player needs to fix the television-chocolate machine. Throughout the game the Oompa Loompas must help Charlie return the chocolate factory back to normal by fixing the mistakes that the self-indulgent children made.

Source: Wikipedia, "Charlie and the Chocolate Factory (video games)", available under the CC-BY-SA License.

boardgame.name: Turtle Soup
boardgame.description:
A press-your-luck game of fraught cuisine for the Decktet.

Flip a card face up and then flip another. Continue until there are cards showing four or more of the six Decktet suits.

Active players simultaneously indicate whether they intend to take a bowl now or wait for more ingredients.

If the additional card makes it so that the face up cards include at least one instance of each of the six Decktet suits, then the soup has gone Turtle Butt. The soup night is over. Return any chips in the pot to the bank. Players who didn't take a bowl get nothing for that night.

The game should be played for at least five soup nights. Obviously, you can make the game longer by playing more nights. In the end, each small chip collected is worth 1 point and each large chip is worth 5. The player with the most points wins.

boardgame.name: Ziggurat Demolition Throwdown
boardgame.description:
Because the world needs more games about dueling wizards.

You are an ancient and powerful wizard living in a community for aged but powerful wizards. The guy across the way bubbles his cauldron much too loud, even though you have asked him to turn it down several times. There was a time when those who disturbed your afternoon tea would feel the force of your eldritch wrath. Perhaps this afternoon will be such a time.

The uses a copy of the Decktet and one Rainbow Pyramid stash for each player. (That's a small, medium, and large pyramid in each of five colours: Red, Yellow, Green, Blue, and Black. Two players can play with an Ice Dice set or two Treehouse sets.) Cards represent spells you have in mind; in the game, this means attacks you can make. Pyramids are your circle of magical instruments; they are what you need to have in place to play cards. Your opponent will whittle away at your pyramids, and you at theirs. The first player to run out of pyramids loses.

boardgame.name: Who is The Doctor?: Demon's Run Standoff
boardgame.description:
‘Demons run when a good man goes to war.’
This is an unauthorised, non-profit, print-and-play game inspired by the BBC TV show Doctor Who episode ‘A Good Man Goes to War’ (Series 6, Episode 7). The basic game mechanism is a kind of reverse werewolf/mafia game where the secret character, The Doctor, is the only person who can’t kill anyone and has to survive on wits and confusion alone.

Background: (Or buy the DVD and watch it!)
Human soldiers and the mysterious headless monks are working together in an uneasy alliance. They have kidnapped The Doctor’s companion (Amy Pond) and taken her to the asteroid know a Demon’s Run. The Doctor arrives on the asteroid disguised as one of the monks but reveals himself and demands Amy’s return. The lights go out and then back on, all orchestrated by the doctor, of course. Now the soldiers are stood there facing the monks. The soldiers know that one of the monks is their feared enemy, The Doctor, determined to foil their plans. All they have to do is to work out which monk is The Doctor in disguise and shoot him before he escapes. But if they shoot the wrong monk they will feel the wrath of their allies and be killed themselves by the monks dying blast. The monks themselves know that the soldiers are trigger happy and might shoot them. It might be best for them to zap any of the trigger happy soldiers before they themselves are killed - at least the other soldiers would know that they were a monk and not The Doctor. But the monks’ plan needs the soldiers and if they lose all of their soldiers then their plans will fail and The Doctor will triumph. The soldiers and monks need to act quickly before The Doctor is able to escape. The scene is set for the Demon’s Run Standoff.

The Game:
The players take on the role of soldiers, headless monks and The Doctor through a series of standoffs. During each standoff: the soldiers try to kill The Doctor; the monks try to direct the soldiers to The Doctor, and The Doctor just tries to survive. At the end of the standoff, points are given to players whose characters are still alive.

I hear this a lot: "Gee Jake, Panty Explosion sounds really neat and I really like the mechanics but I can't get any of my friends to try it and Japanese school girls are weird and really I'd rather play Fill in the blank".

I get that. Not everyone is cool enough to play a stressed out 15 year old high school girl who shoots lightning out of her mouth every time she sees the ghost of her dead dog. Fine. Let's try this instead.

boardgame.name: Jamestown
Jamestown: Legend of the Lost Colony
boardgame.description:
User Summary

Jamestown (Legend of the Lost Colony) is "a neo-classical top-down shooter for up to four players, set on 17th-century British Colonial Mars" [as defined by its official website].

Its style is similar to classic arcades ("handcrafted pixels") and the action is like many shoot-'em-up, but it features an inventive story, 4 different types of playable ships and (local) multiplayer for up to 4 people on the screen at once.
Various "extras" are all included (different difficulty levels, secret scenarios, unlockable ships, etc.).

It received a "honorable mention for Excellence in Audio" during Independent Games Festival 2011.

boardgame.name: Super Conflict
Super Conflict: The Mideast
boardgame.description:
Super Conflict: The Mideast is a Super NES turn-based video game where the player is a commissioned army officer and he has to command his troops to victory during a fictional Gulf War-like combat situation. The blue forces are armed with American weapons while the red forces are armed with Soviet-made weapons. As the game progresses the player is able to control air and naval units.

Super Conflict is played on a hex map in which players try to capture the opponent's "Flag Tank" or "Flag Ship". The map consists of various terrain tiles with movement and defense modifiers. For example, bridges and deserts lower the defense ratings of occupying troops; hills and mountains provide additional defenses but require more fuel to move through. There are over 55 different scenarios and 16 two-player scenarios.

Source: Wikipedia, "Super Conflict: The Mideast", available under the CC-BY-SA License.

What Is This?

Dungeon World is a roleplaying game that uses sweet modern roleplaying techniques to create an old school adventure game feel.

The cool modern ideas are mostly from Apocalypse World, D. Vincent Baker’s game of a post-apocalyptic wasteland. The rollicking adventure feel is taken from editions of Dungeons and Dragons from Advanced Dungeons and Dragons through 4th Edition. The first Apocalypse World/Dungeons and Dragons hybrid was Tony Dowlers Apocalypse D&D. This is a continuation of Tony’s great ideas to a bigger game.

This isn’t the full Dungeon World game. Dungeon World is a complete game, [while] Dungeon World Hack requires Apocalypse World to play it.

boardgame.name: C. C. Higgins Rail Pass
boardgame.description:
C. C. Higgins Rail Pass is a railroad board game that lets you relive the excitement of a railroad executive in the heyday of rail travel.

Basically a roll-and-move game without the dice, passes may be used to facilitate free rail travel. Collect color-coded sets of rail passes as you travel the rails of North American railroad companies of 1920. Plan your routes as you race to designated payday cities utilizing the free travel from the rail passes you obtain along the way. The goal of the game is to garner the most points by combining rail passes into various sets defined by having the most passes in color categories and types of Railroads. C. C. Higgins Rail Pass is a completely luck-free strategy game that is both simple and extremely flexible in play.

New Monster Event cards
New Encounter cards
New Items
New and expanded rules

And a new card type: Hired Guns

boardgame.name: Feenstaub und Fabelwesen
boardgame.description:
from the back of the book

In the tradition of "Verwunschen und Verzaubert" and "Feenwälder, Zauberflüsse" this collection presents four DSA adventures, each with the subject of the work of fairies and the resulting myths, legends and fairy tales. Often these contain than a grain of truth - but caution is advised because especially in the context of the fairies nothing is quite as it seems.
"Drei Schwüre" by Muna Bering leads into the inhospitable Transysilien. Here, under the influence of the demonic rulers many stories have taken a turn into the gloom - but the heroes can make sure that this will not stay that way!
In "Fischerfest" by Carsten Pohl and Caillean Kompe we travel to the Wadden Sea coast of Nostria. Life on the dike and the vagaries of the sea play a role, as do the ruins of a lighthouse.
"Tod eines Geschichtenerzählers" by Astrid Mosler tells us again that not all is what it seems, while the heroes investigate the death of a story teller in Winhall.
"Verwunschen" by Stefan Unteregger finally plays on the edge of the dark Reichsforst, where the presence of fairies is not that unusual - but this also gives rise to many desires.

boardgame.name: BADASS
boardgame.description:
From publisher blurb:

BADASS is not a game that you can attempt to work your way around with logic. In fact, BADASS kicks that logic in the face, twists its arm behind its back and makes it cry for its momma.

Kick a reinforced metal fire door down off its hinges? BADASS
Catch a bullet with your teeth? BADASS
Slice through an Abrams tank with your katana? BADASS
Does it make sense? NO! Does it have to? HELL NO!

In fact the moment you start making sense is the moment you lose your Badass Points, reverting into the mewling pathetic 98-pound weakling you truly are.

boardgame.name: Demonmaster
boardgame.description:
From publisher blurb:

Demonmaster is a Quest for the Chronicles of Arax solo adventure game. It is a two-part Quest; the first part takes place within the pirate town of Gaxdon, while the second takes place in the wilderness beyond.

For eight days and nights you have been at sea, but your journey is nearing its end, a fact for which you are grateful. A little over a week ago you had learned of attacks on the city of Gaxdon, a place known to be a hotbed of thieves, assassins and pirates. Normally, you would avoid a place like that like the plague, but the rumours of these attacks caught your attention and prompted you to investigate.

The attacks, so the rumours said, happened every night by a horde of demons under the control of a demonmaster - an insane summoner of demons who, somehow, is able to control them with the force of their will alone. These men and women are extremely dangerous and unpredictable and are a great force of evil in the world, so you made the decision to see if these rumours were true.

You set sail from Port Bannon on the White Maiden, a merchant ship with a reputation of trafficking stolen goods. Again, this is not something you would normally do, but most respectable ships avoid Gaxdon. Without much choice, you bought passage onboard the White Maiden and set out.

During the voyage the crew tell you what they know. Each night the demons attack from outside the walls, assaulting relentlessly until the dawn. They then disappear before reappearing again as soon as the sun is down. The demonmaster is said to be hiding somewhere outside the city walls, but the exact location has not been able to be determined.

As the ship sails into the harbour you catch your first glimpse of Gaxdon. It is a rundown, ramshackle town, and you get the impression that you are not going to like it here...

boardgame.name: Greatwood Ranger
boardgame.description:
From publisher blurb:

The Greatwood Ranger is a new Hero for you to use in the Chronicles of Arax solo adventure game.

During the Age of Golden Dreams, man, dwarf and elf lived unopposed upon Arax. Civilization flourished, with great cities and fortresses being built.

Within the Greatwood, the elves built magnificent crystal towers to live in. This towers helped focus the magical energy known as mana and aided the elves in their spell casting. In order to gain this crystal the elves had to travel the world in search for it. Thus were born the Greatwood Rangers.

The Rangers journeyed far and wide, looking for sources of the crystal that they could either claim for themselves or trade for from the other peoples of Arax. In this way they learned much about the world and its people.

And then the Age of Golden Dreams ended, and the Age of Darkness and Nightmares began.

The Greatwood was invaded by orcs from the north and undead from the south. The Rangers were called home and, instead of traveling the world, were now tasked with defending the borders of the Greatwood. Slowly but surely the forest was defiled, and its borders pushed ever inwards, though if not for the Rangers the forest home of the elves would probably have already been wiped out.

To this day the Greatwood Rangers still protect the home of the elves, though some have left the woodlands in order to journey the world once more in search of something - anything - that will help them push back the inevitable tide of darkness that threatens to engulf them.

boardgame.name: Ghostwood
boardgame.description:
From publisher blurb:

Ghostwood is a Quest for the Chronicles of Arax solo adventure game. It is a two-part Quest; the first part takes place within the Ghostwood forest itself, while the second takes place beneath Ghostwood.

Standing outside the forest gives you an eerie feeling; after all, the name Ghostwood is well earned. Rumours of spirits and undead haunting the woodlands before you are well known throughout Arax and people avoid the area like the plague. Unfortunately you do not have that luxury.

You have been charged with the responsibility of tracking down the legendary Thunderhammer, a dwarven weapon of great power. It was stolen from the dwarfs of Valijr Keep a little over a week ago but a dwarf-turned-traitor named Brok. The once respected warrior fled with the Thunderhammer to the west, and you have managed to track him to the edge of Ghostwood.

He must have been desperate to escape to have entered the forest, you reason to yourself; either that or Brok was insane. His reasons for stealing the weapon are still unknown at this point, though bribery or outside influence are suspected.

You take a deep breath and prepare to enter Ghostwood. You have a really bad feeling about this, but the dwarfs are paying you good money; that overrides your fear of what you may find so, drawing your weapon, you begin your trek into the forest.

boardgame.name: Ajin Warrior
boardgame.description:
From publisher blurb:

The Ajin Warrior is a new Hero for you to use in the Chronicles of Arax solo adventure game.

Far to the east of mainland Arax lies a small island empire known as Napaj. Most people know very little of this place, and this is not just due to the long distances between the mainland and the empire; the people of Napaj are notoriously secretive, and foreigners are rarely allowed inside their borders.

This is not to say the people of Napaj never leave their lands and journey to the mainland though, for this does happen on occasion. Merchants visit the port cities, bringing exotic silks, spices and foods with them.

And then there are the Ajin Warriors. These men and women belong to an organization even more secretive than normal Napaji society. So secretive, in fact, that they officially don;t even exist.

The Ajin Warriors are elite fighters who, it is said, practice mystical rites that allow them to perform super-human feats. Members of the order sometimes travel to the mainland as spies or emissaries, while at other times they are also seeking adventure or are on specific missions.

In recent times, since the beginning of the Age of Darkness and Nightmares, some Ajin Warriors have arrived on mainland Arax to help stem the tide of evil that is steadily growing and expanding.

boardgame.name: High Elf
boardgame.description:
From publisher blurb:

The High Elf is a new Hero for you to use in the Chronicles of Arax solo adventure game.

While most of the elven people live within the trees, either in shelters built upon the ground or in specially crafted tree-houses high in the branches, some elves live a life of pure luxury.

These elves - the High Elves, as they are called - live in the great crystal towers that exist in within the Greatwood. They are great magic users and, due to the nature of these crystal towers - they focus the natural mana of the land into pools that allow those near them to cast spells of great power - they have become the pinnacle of elven spell casters.

During the Age of Golden Dreams, before the evil came to Arax, the High Elves helped shape the Greatwood and, to a lesser extent, the world around it. When the Age of Darkness and Nightmares began, they instead began to focus their magic on driving back the evil tide that began to spread throughout the world.

Alas, their efforts have been in vain. The Greatwood has been defiled on all sides and the elven people decimated. The High Elves have helped slow the forces of evil but even their immense powers cannot seem to stop them.

Desperately the High Elves seek a way to stop the armies of darkness that now seem poised to conquer Arax. Whether they will or not, only time will tell.

boardgame.name: Heart of Darkness
boardgame.description:
From publisher blurb:

Heart of Darkness is a three-part Quest for the Chronicles of Arax solo adventure game. It consists of 40 Encounters. Part One takes part in the Bloodsands, a hot and parched desert. Part Two takes place in some sand-blasted hills within the Bloodsands, while part three takes place underground.

You are sitting in the war chamber of Lord Carse, leader of the fortified outpost known as Crimsonrock. With you are many advisors, as well as Lord Carse himself. Standing behind the Lord is a figure dressed in a hooded light brown robe, his (or her) features completely hidden.

“Thank you for answering our message,” begins Lord Carse, “and thank you for coming as quickly as you did.” You nod and smile. “We have need of someone brave and daring, such as yourself, to undertake a dangerous mission.” You hadn’t really expected anything less, so you indicate that you are listening. “This is somewhat of a secret, so we trust you will keep this to yourself.

“As you know, this outpost stands very close to the northern edge of the Bloodsands, the great desert that is home to the undead legions. Within this desert is an outcropping of hills and mountains, very tall, that is home to a race of beings whose existence has long been kept quiet. These beings, the Shin’via, as they are called, guard a sacred chamber that is home to an artifact of great - and dark - power. This artifact is said to be the heart of a demonic god, and it has the power to unmake life. Not just simply kill someone, mind you, but unmake them completely as if they had never existed.”

Lord Carse pauses to let this sink in for a few moments before indicating that the brown-robed figure should come forward. The creature lowers its hood, revealing some sort of reptilian face, with beady eyes, sandy coloured scales and a long tongue that flicks in and out like that of a snake or lizard.

“Viash here is an emissary of the Shin’via, and he has come with a dire warning,” continues Lord Carse. “It appears that the undead have learnt of the chambers the Shin’via guard and are now marching on them, ready to throw all they have at gaining the Darkheart, as the artifact is known. This cannot be allowed to happen. Will you go and stop this? Do whatever you must, but the Darkheart must remain within the chambers guarded by the Shin’via or else all of Arax is doomed.”

“I will go,” you say. “When do I leave?”

“Immediately,” replies Lord Carse. “Viash will act as your guide through the Bloodsands. Take plenty of water with you, it would not do for you to die of thirst before completing your mission.” You stand and nod and, along with Viash, prepare to leave.

boardgame.name: Dwarven Stoneguard
boardgame.description:
From publisher blurb:

The Dwarven Stoneguard is a new Hero for you to use in the Chronicles of Arax solo adventure game.

The Dwarven Stoneguard were once the pride of the dwarven strongholds. They were elite warriors, charged with defending the strongholds from the many enemies of the dwarven people: the orc tribes of the north, the goblins from beneath the ground, and the various monsters and savage beasts that roamed the wilderness.

For the most part, they were highly successful. On only one occasion did the fortresses of the dwarf people become compromised, and that was mainly due the corrupting and poisonous magic of the goblins causing illness in many of the Stoneguard. But even then, they were able to overcome this and eject the goblins from their home.

All of this changed at the start of the Age of Darkness and Nightmares. The orc hordes attacked on masse, the goblins found new and powerful magics, and demons and undead monstrosities added to the dwarven problems. Slowly, one by one, the dwarven fortresses began to fall.

The Stoneguard, being the first line of defence for the dwarven people, were blamed for not defending their homes properly. They became maligned amongst their own people even though, in the face of overwhelming odds, they never once faltered or fled, laying down their lives for their homes.

Today, the Stoneguard continue to defend the last two dwarven fortresses left standing from their enemies. They do so with skill, bravery and resolution. Some Stoneguard have left their ancestral homes, traveling out into the wider world in the hopes of finding some sort of aid for the dwarfs. What they have found has left them in despair, yet they continue to fight, never giving up on the hope that, one day, the will push the darkness back and a new age of light will begin.

boardgame.name: Keel-Hauled!
boardgame.description:
Keel-Hauled! is a dice game for 2 to 4 players. Although the game does contain some complexity, it is relatively simple to learn. Play time for a full game of 50 points is usually less than an hour.

Players are pirates who vie for the position of Captain on a pirate ship. To to this, players must roll their dice to assemble sets that first match the number on the "Crew Dice" which represent the Cabin Boy, Ship's Cook, and First Mate. This becomes more challenging as there are limited spaces on the boat for dice sets to be placed, and the first player can change throughout the game.

The game is normally continued until one player scores 30 to 50 points, when the player with the most points overall is dubbed the new Captain of the ship.

Keel-Hauled has been discontinued, and is no longer available at The Game Crafter website.

boardgame.name: Big Boss
boardgame.description:
Played similar with UNO.
The aim is to empty your hand of all cards. When playing with 2 players deal 7 cards each. When with 3 or more deal 6 cards each. The remaining stack of cards are placed in front of the players face down and the top card is them turned over and placed next to the stack.
There are plenty of special cards in this game:
When a "Pick 2"or "Pick 5" card is played, the next player must draw 2or 5 cards or play another 2 card,
"Skip Turn" skips turn.
"Bullet Proof" card blocks any skip or pick card.

Contents:

52 cards

boardgame.name: Mob Boss
boardgame.description: Shuffle deck. Deal out to each player one card at a time until all cards are dealt out. Each player checks their cards and discards all pairs. The player to the left of dealer offers their hand to the player on their left hiding cards from their view. That player then takes one card from the hand. Again, any pairs are discarded. Playing continues. "The Boss" card can be passed around several times. The object is to be left with "The Boss" card. Finally, when all pairs are laid down, there will be one person left with "The Boss" card. That person is "Boss of ‘The Family’".

boardgame.name: Spider-Man: Return of the Sinister Six
boardgame.description:
In the game the player controls Spider-Man through six side-scrolling levels, with a member of the Sinister Six at the end of each level as a boss. The famous super-hero could jump, punch, kick, climb certain walls, shoot unlimited webs to swing on and collect web fluid to shoot square, web projectives. Players can also duck, and perform a jump kick.

The levels were generally pretty straight forward side-scrolling action, although occasionally a particular item such as key or a detonator would have to be found. Each level started out with a graphic illustration of Spider-Man battling the supervillain that the player would fight as a boss.

Spider-Man has only one life (in the NES version), although you do receive one continue. While there are web cartridge icons scattered throughout certain levels, (allowing Spider-Man to shoot ten web projectiles) there are no icons available to restore energy. However, defeating several enemies can restore Spider-Man's power bar.

Source: Wikipedia, "Spider-Man: Return of the Sinister Six", available under the CC-BY-SA License.

boardgame.description:
The hare and tortoise are staging a series of races! This an asymmetric 2 player climbing race game using the Decktet system. Even though the players must shed the same amount of cards, the Hare is given much more to use (and is more free to use them) at the start of the game, but the Tortoise will slowly and steadily build up her hand.

The card play like climbing games is in response to the opponent's plays, but it is also constrained because the players must always connect their plays with their developing race tracks. The winner with the best record after four races is the champion badger!

Full rules may be found on wiki.decktet.com

boardgame.name: Atari 2600 Paddle Controller
CX30
boardgame.description:
A paddle is a game controller with a round wheel and one or more fire buttons, where the wheel is typically used to control movement of the player object along one axis of the video screen. A paddle controller rotates through a fixed arc (usually about 330 degrees); it has a stop at each end.

Atari 2600 Paddle controllers come in pairs both connecting to a single controller port. These controllers also rotate just under one full rotation before hitting a hard stop. Finally, they have a picture of a tennis racquet and the word "paddle" on it. Because two controllers connect to each port and the 2600 has two controller ports, four players simultaneously can play in games that support it.

Design

The paddle wheel is usually mechanically coupled to a potentiometer, so as to generate an output voltage level varying with the wheel's angle relative to a fixed reference position. A paddle is thus an absolute position controller. That is, without any previous knowledge, the sensor can be read and the result directly indicates the position of the paddle knob. This is in contrast to a quadrature encoder-based device or "spinner".

Games

Some famous video games using paddles are Pong, Breakout, and Night Driver. The reason for the name paddles for this type of game controller is that the first game that used it, Pong, was a video game simulation of table tennis, whose racquets are commonly called paddles. Even though the simulated paddles appeared on-screen (as small line segments), it was the hand controllers used to move the line segments that actually came to bear the name.

Source: Wikipedia, "Paddle (game controller)", available under the CC-BY-SA License.

boardgame.name: Powers & Worlds
boardgame.description:
From Introduction:

Powers and Worlds is a bit of an anecdotal behind-the-scenes documentary mixed in with a "how to" guidebook. We'd been asked by the fans to give some help in designing Pulse-wielding powers in various settings, and it was something we really wanted to help out with. But wow! What a tall order! Of all the magic in all the worlds - how could we tackle such a huge task?

While creating the Weapons and Worlds list, the answer came to us; we'd do it the same way - by example. And that's how Powers and Worlds came about. Over the years of play testing different settings with the second edition Suzerain rules, we'd designed over a thousand feats, many of them Pulse powers. By taking some of those examples and talking about them, we hope you get a feel for the ways in which you can develop your own. We only scratch the surface in these pages - the rest is up to you!

boardgame.name: Dualism
boardgame.description:
Dualism is a fascinating puzzle game about polarity. It features 160 levels ranging from easy to hard.

Dualism requires an iPad with iOS 4.2 or higher.

You draw one continuous line on the board and each stone the line touches, will switch its color. Black to white and vice versa.

To finish a level you have to make sure each stone in each row has the same color. But be aware, different rows can have different colors!

Dualism features over 160 challenging levels. 100 levels are included for free. Enough to keep you hooked for hours.

A 10 level tutorial is included, so you can learn to play Dualism hands on.

Dualism is Game Center enabled, so you can share all your solved levels with your friends online!

Source: The Game Website.

boardgame.name: Doom's Knight
Dooms Knight
boardgame.description:
You’ve been punitively posted to Mars after assaulting your commanding officer, who ordered your unit to fire upon civilians. The Martian marine base acts as security for AGM corporation (AGM), a multi-planetary conglomerate, which is performing secret experiments with teleportation by creating gateways between the two moons of Mars, Phobos and Deimos.

Phobos is considered by space marines to be the dullest assignment imaginable: "with no action for eighty million miles, your day consisted of suckin' sand and watchin' flicks in the rec room." This all changes when the AGM experiments go horribly wrong.

Computer systems on Phobos malfunction, Deimos disappears entirely, and "something fragging evil" starts pouring out of the gateway, killing or possessing all AGM personnel. Responding to a frantic distress call from the overrun scientists, the Martian marine unit is quickly sent to Phobos to investigate, where you’re left to guard the hangar with only a pistol while the rest of the group proceeds inside. Over the course of the next few hours, you hear assorted garbled radio messages, gunfire, and screams, followed by silence: "Seems your buddies are dead…or WORSE…"

As the last man standing, your mission is to fight through the entire onslaught of demonic enemies by yourself in order to keep them from attacking Earth.


*** *** ***




If you liked Doom, you'd like Doom's Knight. All new 36 new levels and new sound track will put you in the middle of the action.

Features:
- 36 new levels
- 9 weapons: Fists, Pistol, Shotgun, Chain gun, Rocket Launcher, Plasma Gun, saw, Shotgun, and BFG

boardgame.name: Derelicts of Sin: Heresy
boardgame.description:
Derelicts of Sin: Heresy is the first in a series of games revolving around the Derelicts of Sin and the dark past of the Theocratic Council.

Heresy revolves around Kyle Mason, the sole survivor of a terrible act of sabotage. Hoping to find oxygen before he asphyxiates, Kyle limps his sabotaged ship into a forbidden Cursed Zone called "the Wreckage." There, he boards one of the Derelicts of Sin, the Heresy, desperate to find the supplies he needs to survive and return home.

This solo game seeks to recreate the feel of classic text-based adventures. The player takes on the role of engineer Kyle Mason. Oxygen is used as action points to move, open locked doors, restore power, etc. The player begins on the Airlock tile. As he or she explores the ship, additional tiles are drawn randomly and added to the ship. These tiles provide instructions on how to further advance, reveal the items that can be found in the new room, and detail the the puzzle(s), if any, that must be solved in order to win the game.

In the current version, a player sheet is used to track the player's physical and mental states (which affect the player's ability to search the ship and perform various actions), as well as the player's oxygen level and inventory. Another optional version is in development that will use chart tiles and tokens to track these things.

As the player explores the ship, he or she will find data cards that gradually reveal the terrible fate of the Heresy and its passengers and crew. They also provide victory points that are key to obtaining the specific ending a player desires. Without sufficient victory points, players will lose when they end the game, so it's important to find as many data cards as possible.

This game was developed as part of the Solitaire Print-and-Play Contest at http://boardgamegeek.com/thread/644090/solitaire-print-and-p....

boardgame.name: Ash
boardgame.description:
These are strange days for Aghaus. By order of the Magistrate, the Royal Guard is to assemble for deployment in two days’ time. It has been years since I last left the capital, and further still that I can remember such a command being issued! But what need is there for a Royal Guard, when no King sits upon the throne? Though my oath binds me to his service, the Magistrate is not my liege. He rules in the absence of a rightful heir.

My men await their orders; they too are uneasy. It is for their sake that I stay my tongue, and place my faith in the Almighty that my fears are unfounded.

Tomorrow, we make for the East.

–Captain Creval of the Royal Guard, in the 895th year of our Empire

18 months in the making, Ash, SRRN’s full length RPG for the iPhone and iPod Touch is finally ready for release.

Designed exclusively for the iPhone, Ash is an original turn-based RPG, featuring an all-new, intuitive touch-based interface, lush visuals licensed from Enterbrain, beautifully orchestrated music, and a wonderfully compelling story.

Ash tells the story of two mercenaries on the fringes of the Empire of Aghaus, a once-great kingdom now fallen into ruin after the death of its king five years prior. When a routine contract takes an unexpected turn, the two men are gradually embroiled in a conflict that consumes the entire continent—and brings to light the mercenaries’ mysterious pasts.

Source: The Game Website.

boardgame.name: Atlantida
boardgame.description:
Game Overview

In Atlantida you control a faction of the people of Atlantis that, after a series of catastrophes that turn their once glorious civilization to a semi-barbaric state, must move to the safety of the continent to avoid perish in the island inevitable collapse.
There are 13 turns, in which you must explore the island to gather resources, develop your city and discover technologies and advances in order to be able to send your population to safety. The winner is the first to save all her people or the most efficient to save them in the moment the island collapses.

Game Development

Even though the Atlantida already works as intended and the general idea is defined, it is still subject to changes. The game was developed directly for the yucata.de website, aiming to benefit from multiple plays which can provide a fair amount of players' feedback and suggestions. It is possible to play it "live", though, using the print and play files and rules at the Files section.

Online Play

boardgame.name: Color Connection Maze
boardgame.description:
Game where math skills, color blending, critical thinking and fast-paced, finger-flicking fun meet.

This intriguing game is a fun way for children to explore combinations and blends of colors. For example, by shifting the yellow and blue levers, they guide a marble into the green slot. By shifting the red, yellow and white levers, they guide a marble into the peach slot. To win, all slots must be filled with two marbles of matching colors. It's a great test of visual tracking, mental aerobics and hand-eye coordination.

boardgame.name: Fosfofou
boardgame.description:
A luminous observation game: The cards all look the same at first glance, so it's not so easy to pair them up.

Object of the game is create as many pairs as You can. Players mix the cards then place them on the table with the "5 geometric forms" side facing upwards. All the players play at the same time. Once the signal is given, each player looks at the cards and tries to find identical pairs. As soon as a player thinks he has created a pair, he takes two cards, places them in front of him and continues to search for other pairs. But watch out for mistakes as the cards are very similar!In fact, all the cards contain the 5 same geometric shapes; only their location differs from one card to the other. You are not allowed to touch the cards except to finally take them!

Game ends when there are no more cards in the centre of the table, or it does not seem possible to create another pair (if the players have taken incorrect pairs), each player checks the pairs that he has created. Winner is the player with the most correct pairs.

Components:

48 luminous cards

boardgame.name: PlayStation Vita
PSV
PSVita
boardgame.description:
"The PlayStation Vita (also known as PSVita or PSV) is an upcoming handheld game console under development by Sony Computer Entertainment.It is the successor to the PlayStation Portable as part of the PlayStation family of gaming devices.

The handheld includes two analog sticks, a 5-inch OLED multi-touch capacitive touchscreen, and supports Bluetooth, Wi-Fi and 3G in some models. Internally, the Vita features a 4 core ARM Cortex-A9 core processor and a 4 core SGX543MP4+ graphics processing unit, as well as LiveArea as its main user interface, which succeeds the XrossMediaBar.

A main feature is full backwards-compatibility with all PlayStation Portable games that were digitally released on the PlayStation Network, via the the PlayStation Store. The device's dual analog sticks will be supported in only select games. The system will also upscale and smooth the graphics via a software emulator."

Source: Wikipedia, "PlayStation Vita", available under the CC-BY-SA License.

boardgame.name: Zed by Dawn
boardgame.description:
The world as you knew it has collapsed, flesh eating horrors from your worst nightmares walk the earth, and you're low on ammo..

Welcome to Zed by Dawn.

Object:
Zed by Dawn is a print-and-play solo survival horror dice and card game in the world of Zed Run!!! Before the Citystates, before the Gameshow, there were survivors that tirelessly fought the undead hordes; ZbD pits you against a world gone mad.

Zbd's Combat system requires the player to meet or exceed a number of successes that match the encounters target number, using a custom set of six-sided dice.

Each roll whether it be all six dice or just one die will use the survivors precious resources, Fatigue is use to perform melee attacks, ammo is used to perform ranged attacks and if your survivor is ever out of these resources, they cannot use the matching weapon.

Weapons will lower the needed number of successes to defeat encounters.

Items will be used to replenish your survivors resource pools.

Events encountered will hinder your advancement.

Survive to draw the last card in the ZbD deck and made it through the night. But what will tomorrow bring.

You must manage your resources, acquire supplies, and defeat an endless army of the walking dead; your only goal is to survive.

What you need to play
72 ZbD Cards
6 Survivor Cards
3 Resource Tracking dice (d20)
6 Combat dice (d6)

boardgame.name: Pirate Polo
boardgame.description: Pirate Polo is a frantic live-action game for 2 - 4 "pirates". The game is played using a mini-trampoline as the playing surface. Each player has 5 dice of a single, unique color. In the center of the mini-trampoline is set a heavy, non-fragile cereal bowl. The players space themselves evenly around the mini-trampoline and place all five of their dice on the game surface in front of them. Each player has a polo mallet (at times also known as a serving spoon). On the starting signal, all players strike underneath the mini-trampoline with their polo mallet to try to propel their dice into the bowl. The first player to get all 5 dice in the bowl is the winner. This game is an alternative to the difficult to obtain Piratenbillard.

boardgame.name: Monster Vault: Threats to the Nentir Vale
boardgame.description:
From the Publisher's Website:

Terrifying monsters and villains for your heroic- and paragon-tier campaign.

The Nentir Vale - a frontier land sheltered by mountains and strewn with abandoned farmsteads, ruined manors, and broken keeps - is the perfect base for any Dungeons & Dragons campaign.

Monster Vault: Threats to the Nentir Vale presents statistics, tactics, and lore for an array of new monsters that prowl the Nentir Vale, some of which trace their origins back to the earliest editions of the Dungeons & Dragons Roleplaying Game. Other entries focus on campaign villains present in the Nentir Vale region, among them the Iron Circle, the Tigerclaw Barbarians, the Raven Roost Bandits, and several new villainous groups introduced here for the first time.

The monsters and villains contained within are appropriate challenges for heroic- and paragon-tier characters and fit easily into any home campaign, as well as other Dungeons & Dragons published campaign settings. In addition to a 128-page book of ready-to-play monsters and villains, this product includes 8 die-cut sheets of card stock monster and villain tokens and a double-sided battle map featuring four different encounter locations you can use when running encounters.

boardgame.name: It Came from the Desert (1992)
boardgame.description:
Source: Wikipedia, "It Came from the Desert", available under the CC-BY-SA License.

The TurboGrafx CD version was released in 1992. It was a CD-ROM based game that made use of full motion video with recorded sequences of live actors. There were also action sequences that used drawn graphical elements (not captured, as seen in games such as Mean Streets by Access Software). The side-scrolling action sequence consisted of the player battling ants in tunnels. The TurboGrafx CD version did reuse the graphical elements from the computer version for the overhead battle sequences, but not for any of the character conversation segments.

Unfortunately, this version was marred by poor quality of the video playback of the system, and the limitations of the game console hardware that resulted in side scrolling arcade sequences that were tacky in terms of gameplay. The acting in the video sequences was of B-movie quality by intention, keeping in-line with the source material that served as an inspiration for the game.

Taken from the manual:

The little desert town of Lovelock is in trouble. Atomic testing has created giant mutant ants lead by the Ant Queen of Badness... The Antmind.

As Dr. Horton Pangborne's assistant, you must find a way to stop the ants before they build an A-Bomb and wipe Lovelock off the map. The townfolks don't believe there's a problem and some of them are even under Antmind control.

Object of the Game:
Playing the role of Buzz Lincoln, high-school senior, locate the Queen's nest and destroy her before the Ants' atomic bomb is completed. Avoid being injured, captured or destroyed. Listen carefully for clues. Collect evidence that will convince the Air National Guard to join the fight against the Antmind.

Stages of the Game:
It Came From the Desert takes place over eight days. Each day is divided into 3 parts - morning, afternoon and evening. Each part contains up to 6 or more scenes.

boardgame.name: Heiankyo Alien
boardgame.description:
Source: Wikipedia, "Heiankyo Alien", available under the CC-BY-SA License.

Heiankyo Alien ( Heian-ky Eirian) is a video game created by the University of Tokyo's Theoretical Science Group (TSG) in 1979. The game was originally developed as a personal computer game, and was first published by Denki Onky Corporation as an arcade game in January, 1980. The game has been ported to several other gaming systems since its original release.

The player controls a Heian period police officer (kebiishi) who must defend the capital city (Heian-ky) from an alien invasion by digging holes in the ground and filling them back up after an alien falls inside. The player scores points for every alien trapped, and the quicker the hole is filled up after the alien falls in, the higher the amount of points are scored. The aliens increase in number as the levels progress, and they can escape from holes after a certain period of time elapses or if another alien passes above their hole. The player loses if they come in contact with an alien. There is a time limit for each level, and the number of aliens increases drastically when this limit is reached, essentially preventing the player from completing the level.

Meldac released a Game Boy version of the game in Japan and North America in 1990. This port includes a remake version where a new type of alien appears to chase after the player's character.

User Summary

Taken from the manual:

The time is 1,000 years ago, way back in the Heian Age. The peaceful city of Kyo is suddenly invaded by aliens. A kebiishi (knight of the past) is entrusted to defend the city. He decides to confront the terrible aliens in a bold plan to bury the dreaded beasts alive.

People are being horribly devoured bite by bite by the aliens as they ravages down Miyako Ooji (The city's main street). Without even a hinawaju (type of firearm) to shoot the aliens, the keibiishi has no choice but to try to bury the aliens alive. He sets himself to the task, digging a hole on the road where the aliens are headed.

Then he hides and waits. Should any alien fall into the hole, he must quickly bury it before it can climb back out. In this game, you are to play the role of the keibiishi trying to defend the city.

boardgame.name: Academe
boardgame.description:
Academe is a quick, cooperative, filler card game for 3 players: one Thinker, one Teacher and one Builder. The players must expend and earn Ideas, Knowledge and Material by building inventions. Possible inventions are determined by turning over cards in rounds, and the player must choose which invention to build in each turn. If, by the end of the three rounds of the game, the team has earned enough of these three commodities to build a University, they win the game.

Because it is non-competitive, it can also be easily played by fewer than 3 people, if one player wants to play more than one character. In addition, the commodity targets can be lowered to make the game easy to win, for young children.

boardgame.name: Munchkin 10th Anniversary Shot Glass
boardgame.description:
Publisher's Blurb

Munchkin is not a drinking game. Really.

But don't let that stop you from showing your love of Munchkin with the Munchkin 10th Anniversary Shot Glass. These 1.5 oz glasses are black with the Munchkin 10th Anniversary logo in gold. It's a treasure that any munchkin would be happy to find in his dungeon haul... especially since they come with a special rule.

Munchkin 10th Anniversary Shot Glass Rule

The Munchkin 10th Anniversary Shot Glass may be used in any Munchkin game or its sequels.

When fighting a monster on your turn, you may take one complete shot of Strength Potion* from the Munchkin 10th Anniversary Shot Glass to get a +10 combat bonus. You may do this as many times as you like during a game, but every drink of Strength Potion after the first costs you a level. You may only benefit from one Strength Potion per combat.


The owner of the Shot Glass is the sole judge of what liquid(s) will make up the Strength Potion.




Other

Part of the Munchkin series

Elder Sign
si Jel
Il Segno degli Antichi
Le Signe des Anciens
El Smbolo Arcano
Temn znamen

Znak Starszych Bogw
boardgame.description:
Game description from the publisher:

It is 1926, and the museum's extensive collection of exotic curios and occult artifacts poses a threat to the barriers between our world and the elder evils lurking between dimensions. Gates to the beyond begin to leak open, and terrifying creatures of increasing strength steal through them. Animals, the mad, and those of more susceptible minds are driven to desperation by the supernatural forces the portals unleash. Only a handful of investigators race against time to locate the eldritch symbols necessary to seal the portals forever. Only they can stop the Ancient One beyond from finding its way to Earth and reducing humanity to cinders.

Elder Sign is a fast-paced, cooperative dice game of supernatural intrigue for one to eight players by Richard Launius and Kevin Wilson, the designers of Arkham Horror. Players take the roles of investigators racing against time to stave off the imminent return of the Ancient One. Armed with tools, allies, and occult knowledge, investigators must put their sanity and stamina to the test as they adventure to locate Elder Signs, the eldritch symbols used to seal away the Ancient Ones and win the game.

To locate Elder Signs, investigators must successfully endure Adventures within the museum and its environs. A countdown mechanism makes an Ancient One appear if the investigators are not quick enough. The investigators must then battle the Ancient One. A clever and thematic dice mechanism pits their exploration against monsters and the sheer difficulty of staying sane and healthy, all within the standard game duration of one to two hours.

boardgame.name: Red Baron
boardgame.description:
Red Baron is a low complexity, quick playing board game of World War I air combat. This is not an aerial combat simulation by any means. It is a relatively simple "beer & pretzels" game in which the players use cards to fly their fighters, bombers, and balloons.

The game is two-dimensional (no altitude considerations) and features three aircraft types (fighters, bombers and balloons). Players use cards to maneuver their aircraft (one per card play) with the aim of collecting victory points by shooting down enemy aircraft, bombing ground targets (with bombers) or conducting aerial observation over no man's land (with balloons). The players each start with six aircraft but can vary the assortment in an effort to pursue differing victory strategies.

The game comes packaged in a ziploc bag that contains the 11" by 17" card-stock (unmounted) board, 38 playing pieces (counters), 28 cards and 4 pages of rules.

boardgame.name: Mysterium (1991)
boardgame.description:
Taken from the manual:

Your life long fascination with alchemy is about to be tested. You have come to the famous alchemist Hermetrix and been accepted as his apprentice. The task of an alchemist is to magically convert metals and minerals into gold and other useful items. After a short introduction to alchemy, Hermetrix has sent you to the Mysterium to prove yourself. Here you must find your way through twisting halls created by the Arimasp, a race of giant ants who live in the Mysterium. You must use the pools of transformation with your knowledge of alchemy to create any item you will need. To pass the test, you must learn the nature of each metal and mineral, and the transforming powers of each process: fire, water, acid and mercury. When you have mastered alchemy you may succeed in the final test. You must rescue the giant ant civilization and Cadmia, the alchemist who tried before you.

boardgame.name: Wildcard Football
boardgame.description:
This football strategy game revolves around a pair of selector cups, one for each player. The cups are built into the thick gridiron board and function as dials that determine the play selected by each coach.

The outcome of each offensive play is determined by die rolls in the selector cups. The offensive team rolls for yardage gained. The defensive player rolls two dice that can generate random events like a fumble or a penalty.

Play follows the rules of football with punts, field goals, and every other element of the sport.

The board includes a sliding football marker and a matching first down marker that also slides up and down the field. There is a huge scoreboard plus the rulebook.

Published in 1978 by Wildcard, Inc.

boardgame.name: TT Races
boardgame.description:
This is a simple roll and move game of the TT Races on the Isle of Man. The players take turns rolling dice and moving around the board, a 'satellite photo' style representation of the TT Races course. At various points they encounter obstacles that may slow them down or speed them up. They may land on spaces that cause them to draw Race Situation or Pit Signal cards which can affect their progress positively or negatively.

The game components as listed on the rules card are:

Board (TT Course)
Eight playing pieces of different colours (small plastic motorcycles)
One Throwing/Equipment Holder Box
Two Dice
Once Dice Cup
Six sets of Lap Scoring Cards (each numbered 1 - 6)
Sixty-six Race Situation cards
Sixty-four Pit Signal cards

boardgame.description:
Unpack the whole cycling world on your table! Enter the strategies of the biggest cycling teams in a great family game Arrivée.

Compete in the stages for the jerseys of the best cyclist, World champion, best climber, best sprinter or U-25.

Your journey to victory can become complicated due to sudden weather changes, falls or defects, but team co-operation can help you back to the pack. Refresh your team and have the best performance with the use of a dice, cards and intuitive game mechanism.

Arrivée is the best simulation of cycling race stages in the world!

boardgame.description:
This is game #6 in the Games on Half a Checkerboard Series.

F.I.L.O is a sowing game like those in the Mancala family. Unlike games normally found in the Mancala family, F.I.L.O uses a first in, last out (FILO) mechanism for sowing pieces on the board, which is the basis of its name. This mechanism, combined with the attributes of the 8x4 board, takes F.I.L.O in directions not normally seen with games in the Mancala family.

boardgame.name: Frontjammin'
boardgame.description:
This is #7 in the Games on a Half a Checkerboard Series. Frontjammin' is a game like Backgammon, with its own twists. It also includes a variant using a King piece, which gives the game a bit of a Chess flavor.

In the game, players will roll two dice. If they roll 5-6 on any of the two dice, that counts as a single die roll that a player picks (1-4).

In addition, the game involves pieces being placed in columns and trapping their opponent's pieces. The smaller board also lends to an increased chance of a reversal of fortune.

boardgame.name: 2-5 Skidoo
boardgame.description:
This is game #8 in the Games on Half a Checkerboard Series.

2-5 Skidoo a press-your-luck game for 2 players on an 8x4 board, in the family of games that includes games like Can't Stop, Cosmic Wimpout, 500, Farkle, Ten Thousand, and Pass the Pigs. The name is derived from the phrase “23 skidoo”.

In this game, each of the 4 columns on the 4x8 board correspond to numbers 2-5. During a turn a player rolls 6 six-sided dice (numbered 1-6). They pick three to add up, to beat a target number (this is either zero on their first roll, or what their last total was). The players then take one of the remaining 3 dice and apply it to one of their columns.

If a player can't apply a die to advance one of their pieces, or don't beat their target number, all advancement resets.

Play continues until a player gets all four of their pieces off the board.

boardgame.name: Sherlock
boardgame.description:
Sherlock is a cooperative memory game in which players try to unmask the culprit by collecting cards that exonerate the remaining suspects.

To set up the game, thirty cards are shuffled and placed face-down in a 6x5 grid. Each card shows one of six witnesses on its back and a witness viewing one of the five suspects on its front. On a turn, the active player reveals two cards in the grid. If they match, the player then turns over a third card. If all three cards show show the same suspect, the cards are collected and placed face-up next to the grid. In all other cases, that player turns the cards face-down once again, then flips over one of the ten timing cards, each showing Sherlock's nemesis Moriarty.

If all ten Moriarty cards are flipped, then the players lose the game. If, however, the players remove cards from the grid until only three remain, they have successfully identified the culprit – that is, the suspect who remains – and can claim victory.

A competitive variant is included in the rules which have players competing to collect witness cards. An additional variant rewards points to the player who holds (or doesn't hold) the suspect eventually identified as the culprit.

The Sherlock box also includes eight bonus cards, a new dinosaur and action cards for a fifth player for Ilopeli's Jurassik.

boardgame.name: Dept. 13
boardgame.description:
Dept. 13 is a game in which players use the Steel and Glory System to battle the creatures created by Occult Nazi Forces. Dept. 13 is a secret government agency dedicated to fighting supernatural forces. The game includes super spies (who are identified only by one letter initials), Nazi zombies, ghouls, mad scientists, and themes of occult horror. As with the other games in the S&G system, the battles are very quick and can be fought one-on-one or with players each controlling large groups. Each character has several unique stats, including their fighting ability, and the cost to hire them as a mercenary into your fighting force.

Each turn, players activate a character which can take up to two actions, including fight, move, rest, climb, or stand/go prone. Characters can attack enemies that are one square away for melee attack or may use ranged attack for enemies further away. Fighting is based on power of the weapon, power of the character's attack strength, and power of the enemies defense strike. The hit points are calculated via 2D6 - the power of the attack. For example, if an attack had a total strength of 6 and a 10 was rolled, the attack would have a power of 4. Victory is achieved by having a character remain on a certain part of the board for three complete uninterrupted turns.

boardgame.name: Adventure! Puzzle Road
Daedalian Opus
boardgame.description:
Source: Wikipedia, "Daedalian Opus", available under the CC-BY-SA License.

Daedalian Opus (! Bken! Pazuru Rdo, Adventure! Puzzle Road) was a puzzle game for the Game Boy released in June of 1990. It was one of the few games produced by the little-known software company Vic Tokai. Cover illustration by Lawrence Fletcher. The name of the game was inspired by Daedalus, the mythical character of Greek legend who created the labyrinth.

Gameplay

The game is essentially a series of 36 jigsaw puzzles with Tetris-like pieces known as pentominos that must be assembled into a specific shape. The puzzles start off with rectangular shapes and simple solutions, but the puzzles quickly grow more complex, with odder shapes like a rocket ship, a gun, and even enlarged versions of some of the pentominoes themselves. Each level is timed, and once the timer is started it cannot be stopped until the level is finished. One starts off the game with only three pentomino pieces, and at the completion of each early level, a new piece is awarded to the player. At the final level, the player is given the 2x2 square O tetromino and must complete an 8x8 square puzzle.

After completing each level, the player was given a password to access that level at a later time. Interestingly, each password was a common English four-letter word, so that by guessing common four-letter words, players could potentially access levels they had not actually reached by playing the game.

From the manual:

In the World of Daedalus there are puzzles houses on each of the 42 islands of this very puzzling land. On the first island there are no bridges and no ships. When you enter the puzzle house on this island you will find 3 Daedalian blocks. Your task is to fill up the frame in front of you with the blocks. There can be no space remaining! When this has been done, a bridge will appear, and you can go on to the next island.

However, you are in an apprentice stage until you get up to a point where you are using 12 blocks. While in this stage, you will find three blocks at the first island. When the sprite appears over the bridge, you will get another block and go on to next island by passing through the puzzle house. Only when you have gotten by your apprentice stage with 12 blocks, does the real game begin!

You will encounter many different types of frames. Some will be very challenging, but don't give up! When you have mastered all the puzzles on all islands up to 41, you will be confronted by island 42, where your final task awaits you. Here you will be presented with 13 blocks. Good luck!

boardgame.name: TROLLBURGER
boardgame.description:
The players are gnomes in the employ of a troll on a burger restaurant. The troll told them: "One of you will be fired at the end of the day; the one with worst cash!". The troll will take the customer’s orders and he hope the gnomes make their work fast, very fast; because if they delay an order, the customer (another troll, usually!) will get angry and leave the restaurant without paying.

GAME COMPONENTS

15 order cards
95 product cards
12 counters: 3 green, 3 blue, 3 yellow and 3 red
Rules

GAME PLAY

"Trollburger" is a 2-player card game. At the start of the turn, the starting player turn over the top deck card and show the number on it.

If that number is equal or higher thant the number of order cards on table, another order card is drawn and placed on the table.

Then the starting player choose to perform one of 4 actions on his turn. He can make that action as many times as the number shown at the start of the turn:

-Take cards from the product deck
-Search a card from the product deck
-Discard cards from the hand
-Place products on the table to build a burger

Then, he can choose to deliver a burger to the customers. The player can deliver an incomplete burger, in the hope that the customer does not realize.

Next, the other player takes his turn, using the same number;
and at last he becomes the starting player for the next turn.

If at any time, a 5th order has to be added on tha table, the older order on table is discarded (and any player who was working on it, loses his product cards).

GOAL

When a player devilers an order he takes that order card.
The game ends if 4 orders are discarded or the last order card is drawn.
At the end of the game, each player add the victory points of his order cards. The player with more victory points is the winner.

(Here you can find all the files to print & play your own Trollburger).


Los jugadores son gnomos que trabajan para un troll en una hamburgueseria. El troll les ha comunicado que uno de ellos sera despedido al final del dia; aquel que aporte menos al negocio. El troll es el encargado de coger los pedidos de los clientes y espera que los gnomos hagan su trabajo rapido, muy rapido; pues si se retrasan en entregar un pedido, el cliente (normalmente otro troll!!) se va a enfadar y se ira del restaurante si haber consumido.COMPONENTES DEL JUEGO

15 cartas de pedidos
95 cartas de productos
12 contadores: 3 verdes, 3 azules, 3 amarillos y 3 rojos
Reglas

EL JUEGO

"Trollburger" es un juego de cartas para 2 jugadores. Al principio del turno, el jugador inicial gira la carta superior de la baraja y muestra el número que aparece en ella.

Si ese numero es igual o mayor que el numero de cartas de pedidos en la mesa, aparece una nueva carta de pedido y se añade al centro de la mesa.

Después el jugador inicial elige cual de 4 posibles acciones quiere realizar en su turno. Podra hacer esa accion tantas veces como el numero que se ha mostrado al principio del turno:

-Coger cartas de la baraja de productos
-Buscar una carta en la baraja de productos
-Descartar cartas de la mano
-Colocar productos en la mesa para elaborar una hamburguesa

Despues, puede elegir entregar una hamburguesa a los clientes. El jugador puede entregar una hamburguesa que no este acabada, con la esperanza de que el cliente no se de cuenta.

Acto seguido, el otro jugador realiza su turno, usando el mismo numero; y al final se convierte en el jugador inicial para el siguiente turno.

Si en algun momento, se debe anadir un 5º pedido a la mesa, el pedido mas antiguo que hubiera en la mesa se descarta (y cualquier jugador que estuviera elaborando ese bocata, pierde los productos que tuviera en la mesa).

OBJETIVO

Cuando un jugador entrega un pedido se queda esa carta de pedido.
El juego finaliza si 4 pedidos se han descartado o si se muestra el ultimo pedido del mazo.
Al final de la partida, cada jugador suma los puntos de victoria de sus cartas de pedidos. El jugador con mas puntos de victoria es el ganador.

(Aqui puedes encontrar todos los archivos necesarios para imprimir y jugar a tu propio Trollburger)

boardgame.name: String Railway: Transport
boardgame.description:
String Railway: Transport is a follow-up game to String Railway, a train game in which the play area is created by placing varying lengths of colored string representing different types of terrain. The board is initially seeded with all the stations (unlike in String Railway) placed randomly inside the boundary string and filled with two goods cubes.

Each turn, players must place one string that connects stations. Then players have a number of action points to use. Players start with a 3 AP locomotive, and can upgrade to better locomotives that provide up to 6 AP per turn. Action points are used to moving goods cubes (1 AP to move from station to station). If a cube reaches a station of the same colour as the cube itself, the cube is then scored.

White cubes are special long distance cubes. Players have mission cards that show three stations in particular order. In order to fulfill the mission, the player must move a long-distance cube through the stations in right order. The reward depends on how many stations player moves the cube through. Unfulfilled mission is worth -2. Moving the cube through one station gets rid of the penalty. Two stations gets rid of the penalty and gives the player the white cube, which is scored as a wild cube. Three stations scores 5 points on top of that.

After five rounds, the cubes are scored. Each set of five cubes of different colours is worth 15 points, 4-cube sets are 10 points, 3-cube sets are 6 points, 2-cube sets are 3 points and remaining single cube sets give 1 point each. White wild cubes can be very useful at this point. Unfulfilled missions are -2 points, while perfectly fulfilled missions are +5 points.

In addition of moving cubes, action points can be used for upgrading locomotives and replenishing goods cubes. Collected goods cubes can be discarded to gain AP. Players can also draw new mission cards and each player has a personal station they can place on board at some point in game.

String Railway: Transport, with a playing time of approx. 15 minutes per player, differs from the original game by adding cargo delivery and removing the values of stations. Transport is an individual game, not an expansion. The games are not compatible: you can't play String Railway with the components of Transport (the stations are different and there's no river).

On many of the higher level islands, you must open gates which require certain colored gems (blue, purple, green, orange, red) to open, which you can only get from (currently one) a tree on your own island (but this is only one random colored tree), through random events from digging (receive only a single random gem, but you can share the gems you find with friends), or by requesting friends to send you some.

On each island, there are a certain amount of "Treasures" which contain objects that make up collections. When a collection is completed, the player will receive a reward in the form of money.

Source: Wikipedia, "Treasure Isle (video game)", available under the CC-BY-SA License.

boardgame.name: Freedom
boardgame.description:
Freedom is a two-player abstract strategy board game invented by Veljko Cirovic and Nebojsa Sankovic in 2010. It is played with black and white stones on a square board. The game is related to Go-Moku and Slimetrail. It can be played with a Go set or with pen and paper.

Rules:

Board: Freedom is played on a 10×10 square board. Beginners can try the game on a 8×8 board. Other board sizes may be also used.

Objective: The objective of Freedom is to have more "live" stones at the end of the game, than your opponent. A stone is considered to be "live" if it is a part of some horizontal, vertical or diagonal row of exactly 4 stones of the same color.

Play: A game begins with an empty board. Each player has an allocated color: White and Black. White plays first, putting one white stone anywhere on the board. After this move players take turns placing their stones on empty cells adjacent to the last opponent's stone. If all cells adjacent to the last opponent's stone are occupied then the player gets the right ("freedom") to place his stone on any empty cell of the board. The game ends when the board is filled with stones. The last player has the right to pass on his last turn (and leave the last cell empty) if placing his stone reduces his score.

boardgame.name: Do: Peregrinos del Templo Volador
Do: Pilgrims of the Flying Temple
boardgame.description:
From the website: Do: Pilgrims of the Flying Temple is a storytelling game about helping people and getting into trouble. For 3-5 players, ages 12+.

From the rulebook: Do: Pilgrims of the Flying Temple is a collaborative storytelling game where each player helps create a story, makes trouble for their character and tries to get a happy ending. You write the story of pilgrims flying from one world to the next, helping people they meet and getting in plenty of shenanigans along the way. Misunderstandings will happen. Good intentions will lead to unexpected consequences. Depending on your choices, each leg of the journey will end with your characters hailed as heroes or chased away by an angry mob. It’s a silly universe out there and it only gets sillier the farther pilgrims travel.

De la web del editor:

El universo está lleno de problemas bien gordos. Cuando la gente necesita quién les eche una mano, escriben cartas al Templo pidiendo la ayuda de los peregrinos -unos jóvenes viajeros con buenas intenciones, el poder de volar, y... ¡no mucho más, la verdad! Los peregrinos vienen a ayudar, pero tienden a meterse en montones de líos por el camino. ¡Crecer es de locos!

Do: Peregrinos del Templo Volador es un juego narrativo fantástico lleno de payasadas. Este libro contiene todas las reglas que necesitas para poder jugar. Si le añades un cuaderno, lápices, dos puñados de piedras y unos cuantos amigos, estarás listo para responder a las cartas, ayudar a la gente... y meterte en líos.

boardgame.name: Colgate Crusaders
boardgame.description:
Colgate Crusaders is a children's roll and move game published by the company Colgate Palmolive Ltd. in 1983. It was not available for general purchase in stores but rather was obtainable by sending off for it to the company.

The game is a promotional piece designed to advertise the benefits of Colgate toothpaste and encourage good dental hygiene amongst children. It encourages regular brushing and general use of Colgate products and warns against the dangers of too much sugar, fizzy drinks, etc.

The game is set in the fictional Molar System where the players (each playing as one of the game's heroes; Captain Colgate, Blue Minty Kid, Flick Flouride and Mike Molar) are trying to protect the system by keeping it clear of evil villains. They are constantly on patrol battling against the forces of darkness - Sugary Sam, Sweetie Pie, the Gumboot Boys and the Enamel Animal with his servants the Plaque Monsters.

The aim of the game is to be the first to capture 3 Plaque Monsters and return them to your space ship.

boardgame.name: Rogues in Space, Volume II
Scam
boardgame.description:
From the Introduction:

Scam discusses various aspects of scams, con games, and similar deceptions in the universe of Traveller. Nor does it limit the field of coverage to these criminal activities, though they are important to the supplement; the systems presented in Scam are intended to permit player-characters to attempt a wide variety of deceptions, falsehoods, or impersonations as a part of their ordinary adventuring activities. Thus the material is in no way solely concerned with enabling characters to make money off of their gullible companions. All areas of interpersonal relations which are likely to arise in a given adventure or campaign may be handled by using this supplement.

An Apprentice sorceress at Susthania's School of Magic, you know you're in trouble when your unlocking spell opens everything in the school. Will you fall victim to the spell of evil, or choose wisely for both your heart and your wand?

boardgame.name: Faldor: World of Adventure
boardgame.description:
From the back of the book:

Faldor, a primitive planet only a few parsecs from the borders of the Imperium, but remote in terms of society, technology, and culture. For centuries isolated at the behest of sociologists interested in charting the progress of cultures stranded on the world long ago and reduced to the verge of savagery, Faldor has only recently been opened to contact with traders from the stars. The hazards of dealing with primitive cultures and natural hazards require a courageous and skilled breed of adventurer to meet the challenges of this new world.

The adventures come to Faldor as part of a company trading team, making a routine call at the planet to take on cargo and check on the well-being of company employees on the planet. A routine stop on a routine voyage. But routine can be deceptive, and it's possible that some of the those who come to Faldor may never leave...

Faldor - World of Adventure lies ahead. It is a place of primitive peoples and of potential wealth. But it is also a world full of potential danger...
